body:
SGTM.

On Tue, Mar 22, 2016 at 12:31 PM, Brad Fitzpatrick <notifications@github.com
> wrote:

> I propose we freeze old issues.
>
> @ianlancetaylor <https://github.com/ianlancetaylor>, @minux
> <https://github.com/minux>, @adg <https://github.com/adg> and I spend a
> lot of time telling people to file new issues or move to a forum instead of
> asking questions on years-old closed issues.
>
> I think what happens is people do a web search for some substring of a
> stack trace, find an old code.google.com or github issue tracker result,
> and then ask "This happened to me too. What was the fix?" But the bug
> they're replying to was Go 1.2 era and they're presumably using Go 1.5+,
> and the stack trace they posted isn't actually the same at all.
>
> @gopherbot <https://github.com/gopherbot> could reply with text like:
>
> Auto-freezing close issue. The Go project does not reuse issues. To ask
> related questions, see https://golang.org/wiki/Questions or, if you've
> found a bug, please file a new issue <https://golang.org/issues/new> and
> feel free to reference this one.
>
> And I think the API call from Gopherbot can even do that without sending
> out email.
>
> The issue can still be commented on by project members, and project
> members can unfreeze it if needed.
>
> Thoughts?
>
> â€”
> You are receiving this because you are subscribed to this thread.
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/golang/go/issues/14903>
